close_symbols: enum MHD_Result and constants MHD_YES / MHD_NO / MHD_HTTP_OK
explanation:
Why each symbol is required to judge MISRA C rule (no unreachable code):

- struct Request
  - The function reads and writes req->timerfd and req->connection. You must see the struct layout/type and any invariants (e.g. timerfd semantic) to know whether the branches that test req==NULL or req->timerfd == -1 can ever be taken or are impossible.

- epfd
  - epoll file-descriptor used in epoll_ctl(…). Its declaration/value/usage elsewhere may affect whether the epoll_ctl/registration path (and thus subsequent behavior) is meaningful or can be optimized away; also needed to see if any global initialization makes some branch impossible.

- evt (struct epoll_event variable/declaration)
  - evt is used but not declared in the function; you must inspect its declaration/type/storage (global/local) to determine if the epoll registration side-effect is actually performed and whether that code path is reachable.

- timerfd_create
  - Called to set req->timerfd. Its prototype / attributes are needed to determine whether the call can fail, or whether it is annotated as non-return / has side-effects that could make later code unreachable.

- timerfd_settime
  - Called after creating timerfd. Need prototype/attributes to check for non-return behaviour or side-effects that could affect reachability of code after it.

- epoll_ctl
  - Used to register the timerfd. Its behavior and possible non-return attributes (or wrappers) could make branches unreachable; also errors propagate to printf+return paths.

- TFD_NONBLOCK, CLOCK_MONOTONIC, EPOLLIN, EPOLL_CTL_ADD
  - These macros/constants are used in system calls; their definitions are required to understand the semantics of the system calls (and whether any macro expansion hides non-standard control flow or attributes).

- MHD_suspend_connection
  - Critical: if this function is declared with noreturn/longjmp semantics, the following return statement would be unreachable. You must inspect its declaration/attributes/implementation to decide if any code after the call is unreachable.

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_copy
  - Prototype/implementation may contain attributes or calls that affect control flow (e.g. longjmp/noreturn). Need to confirm it behaves as a normal returning function so the caller's subsequent code is reachable.

- MHD_queue_response
  - Its return value is propagated by ahc_echo. If this function were noreturn or had side-effects that prevented return, it would affect reachability of code following its invocation; check its declaration/attributes.

- MHD_destroy_response
  - As above: check whether it can be noreturn or have attributes that affect reachability.

- enum MHD_Result and constants MHD_YES / MHD_NO / MHD_HTTP_OK
  - Needed to interpret return statements and return-value-based control flow (and to check if any of these macros expand to control-flow affecting constructs).

- malloc
  - Allocation failure branch returns MHD_NO; need to ensure malloc is standard and not replaced by something that aborts (which would make subsequent code unreachable).

- strlen
  - Used to compute response length; verify it is a normal returning library call and does not change control-flow properties relevant to reachability.

- errno and strerror and printf
  - Error reporting path is taken on certain failures; ensure those symbols are normal functions/macros and not non-returning wrappers (which would make later code unreachable).

Summary: focus is on symbols that can change control flow semantics (noreturn/longjmp/attribute) or determine the truth of the key branch conditions (struct Request timerfd field, global epoll state). Inspecting the listed symbols lets an analyzer decide whether any blocks in ahc_echo are statically unreachable (e.g. code after a call that never returns, branches that can never be true given object layouts/initialization).
